entry.title: Re: How to generate purchase order output on change of a purchase order?
entry.content:
Dear colleagues,

we have set up the S/4HANA Output Management for Purchase orders and for Purchase order change in an on-premise system. Now we would like to have a different email template for each case. Is there any chance to do that without adding a new field as a change indicator?

Thanks a lot, Lisa

entry.title: Re: Can I extend a certain app? With Clean Core? How?
entry.content:
Hi @Gowthami5 

If you need to add standard/calcutated fields but the CDS view you need to extend isn't released with a C0 contract, then yes, you can still do it, as long as you are in ABAP language version Standard ABAP (as opposed to ABAP for Cloud Development, which is clean core by deefinition). Which means your extension is not clean core compliant, as upgrade stability cannot be guaranteed, as there is the missing C0 contract.

You correctly determined that using Custom Fields would be wrong here; custom fields are only for brand-new fields that are persisted in the database. If you do not want/need that, don't use custom fields.

The approach here would be to do the extension in Standard ABAP, as that would still be the better solution, than creating a copy of the app. One other approach could potentially be to create your own custom OData service, with all the fields you need, and use that in a Fiori adaptation project. However that option has many "buts". If the original CDS views have parent-child relationships, you'd be forced the create custom ones of each of those, even when selecting from the original CDS, that is a lot of work an a lot of "copies". 

So simply put this in a package for not ABAP Cloud, monitor it, and you should achieve your goal.

Regards

entry.title: Re: SAP DIGITAL MANUFACTURING - TRANSFER ERP PERSONNEL NU...
entry.content:
Hi,

Under Production Order Activity Confirmation, there is the RFC CO_MES_PRODORDCONF_CREATE_TT (I’ve checked it inside SAP IS).

 

If I understood your issue correctly, you could consider encapsulating this RFC within an OData service, configure it in the Manage Service Registry, and then call it from a PPD when the process is completed.

Just remember to update the collaboration links (no automatic confirmation on sfc complete otherwise you will have double confirmations), and make sure to complete the SFC by checking whether all required steps have been performed using the SFC Complete API, also within the PPD.

entry.title: The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management (EWM)
entry.content:
The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management (EWM)

A Practical Handbook for End Users, Key Users, and Consultants

Introduction

Welcome to the world of modern logistics with SAP S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). If you're coming from an older SAP ECC system with Warehouse Management (WM), you're in for a significant upgrade. If you're new to SAP logistics, you're starting in the right place.

This guide is designed to be your single point of reference, whether you're an end user processing daily transactions, a key user training your team, a consultant implementing the system, or a "dummy" who just wants to understand how it all works.

We will transform legacy, custom processes into standard, best-practice S/4HANA EWM functionalities, focusing on modern SAP Fiori applications and a seamless, integrated workflow that spans the entire supply chain.

From WM to EWM: What's the Big Deal?

Think of the classic SAP WM module as a well-organized personal library. It knows which bookshelf (storage bin) a book is on and can help you find it.

EWM, on the other hand, is like the entire Amazon fulfillment center infrastructure. It doesn't just know where the book is; it manages the entire process with incredible detail:

  • Labor Management: Tracking how long tasks take.
  • Wave Management: Organizing picking for multiple orders simultaneously.
  • Slotting: Optimizing where products should be stored based on demand.
  • Value-Added Services (VAS): Managing kitting or special packaging.
  • Advanced RF/Mobile Functionality: Modern, user-friendly mobile interfaces.

This guide will walk you through this powerful system, making it simple and accessible.

Chapter 1: The Foundation - Master Data

Everything in SAP starts with clean master data. Without it, no process can run correctly. We'll focus on the essential objects for our end-to-end warehouse flow.

1.1 The Business Partner (BP)

In S/4HANA, the old concepts of "Customer" and "Vendor" are unified into a single object: the Business Partner. A single BP can have multiple roles.

  • What is it? A BP represents a person, organization, or group your company interacts with. It holds all the core data like name, address, and bank information.
  • How to Manage it:
    • Fiori App: Manage Business Partner Master Data
    • SAP GUI: Transaction BP
  • Key Concepts:
    • General Role: The basic data for the entity.
    • Customer Role (FI Customer / Customer): Contains financial accounting data (like reconciliation account) and sales-specific data (like shipping conditions).
    • Supplier Role (FI Vendor / Supplier): Contains financial data and purchasing-specific data.
    • For our warehouse processes, a BP must have the appropriate Customer role to receive goods and the Supplier role to procure materials from.

1.2 The Material Master

The Material Master holds all information about a product. In S/4HANA, this is now often called the "Product Master," but the core concepts and transaction (MM01) remain.

  • What is it? The central record for every material you procure, produce, store, or sell.
  • How to Manage it:
    • Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data
    • SAP GUI: MM01 (Create), MM02 (Change), MM03 (Display)
  • Key Views for EWM:
    • Basic Data 1 & 2: Core information like material number, description, and unit of measure.
    • Sales Views: Essential for the outbound process. Defines the delivering plant and tax information.
    • Purchasing View: Crucial for the inbound process. Defines the purchasing group and order unit.
    • Plant Data / Stor. 1 & 2: Defines the storage location and basic warehousing parameters.
    • Warehouse Management 1 & 2: In ECC, this was for WM. In S/4HANA, these views are still used for basic data, but the detailed EWM data is stored elsewhere.
  • Practical Exercise 1: Create a Finished Good
    1. Launch the "Manage Product Master Data" Fiori app.
    2. Click "Create."
    3. Enter a Material Number (e.g., FG-1001), Material Type (FERT - Finished Good), and select the necessary views (Basic Data, Sales, Plant Data, Storage Location).
    4. Fill in the required fields like Description, Base Unit of Measure (EA for Each), and assign it to your Plant (e.g., 1000) and Storage Location (e.g., 1030).
    5. Save the material. You now have a product ready to be managed in EWM!

1.3 The EWM Product Master

Once a material is created, it must be "extended" to the warehouse, creating an EWM-specific view of the product.

  • What is it? An extension of the Material Master that holds EWM-specific data, such as putaway strategies, stock removal rules, and packaging specifications.
  • How to Manage it:
    • Fiori App: Manage Product Master Data (navigate to the warehouse views)
    • SAP GUI: /SCWM/MAT1
  • Key Data Tabs:
    • Warehouse Data: Define the Warehouse Process Type (WPT) for putaway and stock removal. For example, a fast-moving item might have a different removal strategy than a slow-moving one.
    • Slotting: Define parameters that help the system determine the optimal storage bin for this product.
    • Storage Type Data: Define specific parameters for how the product is stored in different storage types (e.g., fixed bins, bulk storage).
  • Consultant Corner: Customizing Point
    • The strategies and control indicators you see in the EWM Product Master are configured in SPRO or CBC under: SCM Extended Warehouse Management > Extended Warehouse Management > Master Data > Define Warehouse Process Type. Here, you define the logic for how the system handles movements like putaway, picking, or internal transfers.

1.4 Packaging Specifications

This master data defines how a product is to be packed. It's the foundation of Handling Unit Management (HUM).

  • What is it? A set of rules defining how many "eaches" go into a carton, how many cartons go onto a pallet, the packaging material to be used, and the total weight/volume.
  • How to Manage it:
    • SAP GUI: /SCWM/PACKSPEC
  • Example: For our product FG-1001:
    • Level 1: 1 EA of FG-1001 is packed into packaging material CARTON-S.
    • Level 2: 50 CARTON-S are packed onto packaging material PALLET-EU.
    • When you receive or pick 50 units, the system will automatically know it should be on a single pallet. This replaces the manual logic seen in the old Z4WM programs for palletization.

Chapter 2: Inbound Logistics - From Purchase to Putaway

This chapter covers the end-to-end process of receiving goods from an external supplier into your EWM-managed warehouse. We will model the process described in the source documents (RéceptionFournExt, MIGO, VL31N) using a modern S/4HANA approach.

Process Flow:

Purchase Order -> Inbound Delivery -> EWM Warehouse Tasks -> Goods Receipt

2.1 Create Purchase Order (PO)

This is the starting point, where the purchasing department orders goods from a supplier.

  • Who does it? Purchaser
  • How to do it?
    • Fiori App: Manage Purchase Orders
    • SAP GUI: ME21N
  • Key Steps & Data:
    1. Enter the Supplier (Business Partner with Supplier role).
    2. In the item overview, enter the Material number (e.g., RAW-MAT-01), Quantity, Plant, and Storage Location.
      • Crucially, this storage location must be linked to your EWM warehouse.
    3. On the "Confirmations" tab of the item details, ensure a Confirmation Control Key is used that requires an Inbound Delivery (e.g., Z003 from the source doc, now a standard key like 0004). This is a critical integration point.
    4. Save the Purchase Order.

2.2 Create Inbound Delivery

The Inbound Delivery is a notification that a shipment is on its way. It's the key document that connects Logistics Execution (LE) with EWM.

  • Who does it? Can be created manually by a warehouse clerk or automatically via an Advanced Shipping Notification (ASN) from the supplier.
  • How to do it?
    • Fiori App: Create Inbound Delivery
    • SAP GUI: VL31N
  • Key Steps & Data:
    1. Reference the Purchase Order you just created.
    2. Enter the delivery quantity.
    3. Handling Units (HUs): If the supplier sent an ASN with HU information, you can pack the delivery here. If not, you will create the HUs inside the EWM warehouse.
    4. Save the Inbound Delivery.
  • Behind the Scenes: As soon as you save, this Inbound Delivery is automatically replicated to the EWM system, creating an Inbound Delivery Notification and then an Inbound Delivery within EWM.

2.3 EWM Inbound Processing

This is where the physical work in the warehouse begins. All these steps are typically performed on a mobile RF device, but can also be executed using desktop Fiori apps.

  • Who does it? Warehouse Operator
  • Key Fiori Apps:
    • Warehouse Monitor (for an overview)
    • Process Warehouse Tasks
    • Post Goods Receipt for Inbound Delivery
  • Step-by-Step EWM Flow:
    1. Goods Arrival: The truck arrives at the warehouse. The delivery is checked in.
    2. Unloading & HU Creation:
      • The operator is directed by the system to unload the pallet.
      • If the goods are not already in an HU, the operator will now create them. This replaces the old custom transaction Z4WM08 or Z4WM19.
      • Standard Process: Using an RF device, the operator scans the product, enters the quantity, and scans a pre-printed barcode label to create a new HU number. The system prints a new HU label to be applied to the pallet.
    3. Putaway Task Execution:
      • The system automatically creates a Warehouse Task (WT) to move the HU from the goods receipt area (e.g., storage type 9010) to its final storage bin.
      • The system determines the destination bin based on the putaway strategy defined in the EWM Product Master (e.g., next empty bin, fixed bin, bulk storage).
      • The RF device guides the operator: "Pick up HU 12345. Take it to Bin A-01-03."
    4. Task Confirmation: Once the operator scans the destination bin, the WT is confirmed in the system. The stock is now physically and systemically in its final location.

2.4 Post Goods Receipt (PGR)

This is the final financial step. It tells the system that you legally own the goods, updates inventory quantities in real-time, and allows for invoice verification.

  • Who does it? Warehouse Clerk
  • How to do it?
    • Fiori App: Post Goods Receipt for Inbound Delivery
    • SAP GUI: /SCWM/PRDI (in EWM)
  • Process:
    1. The warehouse clerk finds the Inbound Delivery in the app.
    2. The system shows that all putaway tasks are complete.
    3. The clerk clicks "Post Goods Receipt."
  • Integration Impact:
    • Inventory Management (MM): The stock is now visible in the plant/storage location (e.g., using transaction MMBE).
    • Financial Accounting (FI): An accounting document is created, debiting inventory and crediting the GR/IR (Goods Receipt / Invoice Receipt) account.
    • Purchasing (MM): The Purchase Order history is updated to show the goods have been received.
  • Consultant Corner: The link between an MM storage location and an EWM warehouse is a key configuration point. It's done in SPRO/CBC under: Enterprise Structure > Assignment > Logistics Execution > Assign warehouse number to plant/storage location.

Chapter 3: Outbound Logistics - From Sale to Shipment

This chapter details the process of selling a product, picking it from the warehouse, packing it, and shipping it to the customer. This replaces the legacy processes seen in GU_Expedition du magasin central and 124_ERP606_BPD.

Process Flow:

Sales Order -> Outbound Delivery -> EWM Tasks (Picking, Packing, Staging) -> Goods Issue

3.1 Create Sales Order

The process starts when a customer places an order.

  • Who does it? Sales Representative
  • How to do it?
    • Fiori App: Create Sales Orders
    • SAP GUI: VA01
  • Key Steps & Data:
    1. Enter the Customer (Business Partner with Customer role).
    2. Enter the Material to be sold and the Quantity.
    3. The system performs an Availability Check (ATP) to confirm if the stock is available and proposes a delivery date.
    4. Save the Sales Order.

3.2 Create Outbound Delivery

Based on the sales order, an Outbound Delivery is created when the material is due for shipping.

  • Who does it? Shipping Specialist / Can be automated
  • How to do it?
    • Fiori App: Manage Sales Orders (select the order and choose "Create Delivery")
    • SAP GUI: VL01N or VL10E for collective processing.
  • Process:
    1. The system copies relevant data from the Sales Order.
    2. The Storage Location on the delivery must be EWM-managed.
    3. Save the Outbound Delivery.
  • Behind the Scenes: Just like in the inbound process, this document is replicated to EWM, creating an Outbound Delivery Request and then an Outbound Delivery Order.

3.3 EWM Outbound Processing

This is where the complex orchestration of picking, packing, and staging happens.

  • Who does it? Warehouse Operator
  • Key Fiori Apps:
    • Run Outbound Process
    • Pack Handling Units
  • Step-by-Step EWM Flow:
    1. Wave Creation (Automation): The system can automatically group Outbound Delivery Orders into waves based on criteria like shipping time, route, or customer. This allows for efficient, consolidated picking.
    2. Warehouse Task (WT) Creation: The system creates picking WTs for the wave. It determines the source bins based on stock removal strategies like FIFO (First-In, First-Out) or LIFO.
    3. Picking:
      • The RF device directs an operator to a source bin: "Go to Bin A-01-03. Pick 10 EA of FG-1001."
      • The operator picks the items and confirms the quantity on their device. They place the items into a picking cart or pallet. The system now knows the stock is in transit within the warehouse.
    4. Packing: This is the standard replacement for the old custom palletization programs (Z4WM09, Z4WM10, Z4WM11).
      • The operator takes the picked items to a packing station.
      • Fiori App/RF Screen: "Pack Handling Units" (GUI: /SCWM/PACK).
      • The operator scans the products and the packaging material (e.g., a shipping carton). The system, using the Packaging Specification master data, validates the packing.
      • Once packed, a new HU (the shipping carton or pallet) is created, and a shipping label is printed.
    5. Staging:
      • The system creates a final WT to move the packed HU from the packing station to the shipping area (e.g., Storage Type 9020, Staging Bay for Route A).
      • The operator moves the HU and confirms the task.

3.4 Post Goods Issue (PGI)

This is the final step, marking the transfer of ownership to the customer and the physical departure of the goods.

  • Who does it? Shipping Clerk
  • How to do it?
    • Fiori App: Run Outbound Process
    • SAP GUI: /SCWM/PRDO (in EWM)
  • Process:
    1. The clerk finds the Outbound Delivery Order.
    2. Once the truck is loaded, the clerk clicks "Post Goods Issue."
  • Integration Impact:
    • Inventory Management (MM): The stock is deducted from the warehouse.
    • Financial Accounting (FI) / Controlling (CO): An accounting document is created debiting Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) and crediting the inventory account.
    • Sales and Distribution (SD): The billing due list is updated, allowing the finance department to create an invoice for the customer.

Chapter 4: Internal Warehouse Processes & Inventory

Warehouses are dynamic. This chapter covers essential internal operations, replacing the functions of old transactions like Z4WMxx for transfers, palletizing, and inventory.

4.1 Ad-Hoc Moves & Rearrangements

Sometimes you need to move stock manually for reasons outside of the standard inbound/outbound flow (e.g., consolidation, quality inspection).

  • Standard Process: This replaces the various custom transfer transactions (Trasf cartoni, Tras paletta, Tras Ubi a Ubi).
  • How to do it?
    • Fiori App: Process Warehouse Tasks (create an ad-hoc task)
    • SAP GUI: /SCWM/ADHU (Move Handling Unit) or /SCWM/ADPROD (Move Product).
  • Practical Exercise 2: Move a Pallet
    1. Launch transaction /SCWM/ADHU.
    2. Enter your Warehouse Number.
    3. In the "Source HU" field, scan or enter the HU number you want to move.
    4. In the "Destination" section, enter the Storage Bin where you want to move it.
    5. Execute. The system creates and confirms the WT in one step. The stock is moved.

4.2 Replenishment

This is the process of moving stock from a reserve storage area to a forward picking area to ensure pick faces are always stocked.

  • What is it? An automated or planned internal stock transfer.
  • Key Concepts:
    • The system monitors the stock levels in the picking bins.
    • When the stock drops below a pre-defined minimum quantity (set in the Product Master), the system automatically creates a replenishment WT.
    • An operator is then directed to move a full pallet or case from the reserve area to the picking bin.
  • Consultant Corner: Replenishment strategies are highly configurable. They are set up in SPRO/CBC under: SCM Extended Warehouse Management > Extended Warehouse Management > Internal Warehouse Processes > Replenishment. You can define different strategies like Planned, Automatic, or Order-Related replenishment.

4.3 Physical Inventory (PI)

This is the process of counting your physical stock to ensure the system data is accurate. EWM offers flexible and efficient ways to do this, replacing the old Z4WM22 and Z4WM23 processes.

  • How to do it?
    • Fiori App: Manage Physical Inventory Documents
  • Standard PI Process Flow:
    1. Create PI Document: The warehouse manager decides what to count (e.g., a specific storage type, a range of products) and creates a PI Document.
    2. Counting:
      • A warehouse operator receives the count document on their RF device.
      • They go to the specified bins and count the products/HUs.
      • They enter the count results directly into the device. The PI document is updated in real-time.
    3. Analyze Differences: The manager reviews the count results in the Fiori app. The system highlights any discrepancies between the counted quantity and the system quantity.
    4. Recount (if necessary): If there's a large difference, the manager can trigger a recount for that specific bin.
    5. Post Differences: Once the count is finalized, the manager posts the differences.
  • Integration Impact: Posting differences in EWM automatically triggers a corresponding posting in Inventory Management (MM) and creates a financial document in FI to adjust the value of the inventory and write off the loss/gain.

Chapter 5: Special Processes & Financial Integration

This chapter handles more complex scenarios like customer returns and the resulting financial documents, modernizing the processes from Retour marchandise and ND et NC.

5.1 Advanced Returns Management

When a customer returns a product, you need a robust process to handle the physical and financial aspects. S/4HANA provides a standard "Advanced Returns Management" solution.

Process Flow:

Returns Order -> Inbound Delivery for Return -> Quality Inspection (in EWM) -> Financial Settlement

  • Step 1: Create Returns Order
    • A Customer Service agent creates a Returns Order (VA01, order type ZCRN in the source doc, now a standard type like CBAR). They reference the original sales order or invoice.
  • Step 2: Goods Receipt & Inspection
    • The physical return follows a process similar to the standard inbound flow, but the stock is received into a special "Returns" storage type and is often in a "Blocked" or "Quality Inspection" stock status.
    • A quality inspector is notified. They inspect the goods.
  • Step 3: Logistical Follow-Up (in EWM)
    • Fiori App: Material Inspection in Warehouse
    • Based on the inspection, the inspector decides the follow-up action:
      • Return to Stock: If the product is fine, create a WT to move it to a standard storage bin.
      • Scrap: If damaged, create a WT to move it to a scrap zone.
  • Step 4: Financial Settlement
    • Once the logistical follow-up is complete, the system can automatically trigger the creation of a Credit Memo Request.
    • This is then approved and becomes a Credit Memo (NC), which is sent to the customer, clearing their account. This is the standard, integrated replacement for the manual ZNCN process described in the Italian document. The process for a Debit Memo (ND) follows a similar path if you need to charge the customer.

5.2 Quality Management (QM) Integration

EWM is tightly integrated with QM for processes like acceptance sampling on incoming goods or in-process inspections.

  • Standard Process:
    1. When goods are received from a supplier, if the material is marked for quality inspection, the stock is automatically posted to "Quality Inspection" stock in EWM.
    2. An Inspection Lot is created in the QM module.
    3. A Quality Technician performs the required tests and records the results.
    4. They make a Usage Decision (UD) in the QM system (e.g., Accept or Reject).
    5. This UD triggers an automatic stock posting change in EWM, moving the stock from "Quality Inspection" to "Unrestricted Use" (if accepted) or "Blocked Stock" (if rejected). This replaces the manual status change transactions mentioned in the documents (Z4WM18, Z4WM17).

Chapter 6: The Comprehensive Test Plan

This test plan provides a structured framework for validating the end-to-end processes described in this guide. It is designed for all user types to ensure the system functions as expected.

Instructions: For each test case, follow the steps precisely. Record the document numbers you create. Compare the Actual Result with the Expected Result and mark the Status as Pass/Fail.

Test Area 1: Inbound Logistics

Test Case ID

Scenario

Pre-requisites

Test Steps

Expected Result

Actual Result & Data

Status

TC-INB-001

Standard Goods Receipt of Palletized Goods

Material RAW-MAT-01 exists and is extended to EWM. Supplier SUPP-1001 exists.

1. Create Purchase Order for 100 EA of RAW-MAT-01. 2. Create Inbound Delivery (VL31N). 3. In EWM (/SCWM/PRDI), check the delivery. 4. Process Unload & Putaway tasks (/SCWM/MON or RF). 5. Post Goods Receipt.

- Stock is visible in the final EWM bin. - GR is posted in MM (MMBE). - PO history is updated. - FI document is created.

  

TC-INB-002

Goods Receipt with HU Creation in Warehouse

Same as above.

1. Create PO & Inbound Delivery. 2. At the GR zone, use RF/desktop to create a new HU for the 100 EA. 3. Process the putaway task for the newly created HU. 4. Post Goods Receipt.

- A new HU is created in the EWM system. - Stock is located in the final bin under this new HU number. - GR is posted successfully.

  

Test Area 2: Outbound Logistics

Test Case ID

Scenario

Pre-requisites

Test Steps

Expected Result

Actual Result & Data

Status

TC-OUT-001

Standard Pick, Pack, and Ship

Material FG-1001 has sufficient stock in an EWM bin. Customer CUST-2001 exists.

1. Create Sales Order for 10 EA of FG-1001. 2. Create Outbound Delivery (VL01N). 3. In EWM (/SCWM/PRDO), create picking WTs. 4. Confirm picking WTs. 5. At a packing station (/SCWM/PACK), pack the 10 EA into a new HU. 6. Confirm the staging WT. 7. Post Goods Issue.

- Stock is removed from the EWM bin. - The Outbound Delivery is fully processed. - Goods Issue is posted in MM. - COGS is posted in FI. - The Sales Order is updated as delivered.

  

TC-OUT-002

Picking with Batch Determination (FIFO)

Material FG-BATCH-01 exists with two different batches in stock (Batch A received yesterday, Batch B received today).

1. Create Sales Order for FG-BATCH-01. 2. Create Outbound Delivery. 3. Check the created picking WT in EWM.

- The system should automatically create the picking WT for Batch A (the older batch) based on the FIFO strategy.

  

Test Area 3: Internal & Inventory Processes

Test Case ID

Scenario

Pre-requisites

Test Steps

Expected Result

Actual Result & Data

Status

TC-INT-001

Ad-Hoc HU Movement

An HU with stock exists in Bin A.

1. Use transaction /SCWM/ADHU. 2. Enter the HU number and a valid empty Destination Bin B. 3. Execute.

- The HU is moved from Bin A to Bin B in the system. - The stock monitor (/SCWM/MON) reflects the new location.

  

TC-INV-001

Physical Inventory Count with Difference

Product FG-1001 has a system stock of 50 EA in a bin.

1. Create a PI Document for the bin. 2. Using RF/desktop, enter a count of 48 EA. 3. In the PI Document, review the difference. 4. Post the difference.

- The system shows a negative difference of 2 EA. - After posting, the system stock in the bin is updated to 48 EA. - An FI document is created to write off the value of 2 EA.

  

Test Area 4: Special Processes

Test Case ID

Scenario

Pre-requisites

Test Steps

Expected Result

Actual Result & Data

Status

TC-RET-001

Customer Return and Credit

A sales order has been previously delivered and invoiced to a customer.

1. Create a Returns Order, referencing the original invoice. 2. Create an Inbound Delivery for the return. 3. Receive the goods in EWM into a "Returns" area. 4. Perform an inspection and decide to "Return to Stock". 5. Process the stock movement in EWM. 6. Verify the creation of a Credit Memo Request in SD.

- Stock is successfully returned to an unrestricted-use bin. - A Credit Memo Request is ready for the finance team to process, ensuring the customer is credited correctly.

entry.title: Introducing SAP HANA Cloud on SAP Cloud Infrastructure
entry.content:
We are pleased to share that SAP HANA Cloud is now generally available on SAP BTP powered by SAP Cloud Infrastructure. This new deployment option complements our existing offerings on hyperscaler platforms, addressing the growing demand for technological independence, local compliance, and data control.

About SAP Cloud Infrastructure

SAP Cloud Infrastructure (SCI) is SAP's own Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) platform, operated from SAP data centers around the globe. Built on OpenStack APIs, it provides hyperscale-like capabilities including compute, storage, and networking. Originally designed to run SAP cloud applications with high scalability, resilience, compliance, and security, SCI now also supports selected customer and partner workloads. To explore the platform and its features, visit the SAP Cloud Infrastructure Documentation.

How the new deployment fits into SAP's multi-cloud strategy

SAP gives customers the flexibility to run SAP HANA Cloud on the infrastructure that best meets their needs. Today, it's available on the leading hyperscalers—Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud Platform, and Alibaba Cloud—leveraging our partners' global reach and modern infrastructure. See SAP HANA Cloud data centers.

By adding SAP Cloud Infrastructure as a deployment option alongside the hyperscalers, we give customers even more choice and flexibility, while meeting requirements for technological autonomy, data residency, and access control in the public cloud.

First region and initial scope

SAP HANA Cloud is now live in the SAP BTP Europe (Frankfurt) region on SCI. This cloud-in-country deployment keeps customer and backup data local, ensuring data residency and compliance.

Operating in EU Access mode, the SCI-based deployment restricts the processing of personally identifiable customer data to SAP delivery units located within the European Economic Area (EEA) and Switzerland, giving customers enhanced control and data protection.

On SCI, SAP HANA Cloud delivers the same capabilities and benefits as on hyperscalers*, along with the same SLAs and pricing models, ensuring a consistent experience regardless of deployment choice.

What's next?

SAP HANA Cloud is expanding alongside SAP BTP into new SCI regions. Additional SCI regions are planned for upcoming releases—check the latest SAP HANA Cloud data center availability in SAP Roadmap Explorer.

Summary

With SAP HANA Cloud, customers can choose the infrastructure provider that best fits their business—either a partner hyperscaler or SAP itself. The first SAP BTP region on SAP Cloud Infrastructure is Europe (Frankfurt). With EU-Access, in-country hosting, and enterprise-grade SLAs, this region provides compliance, security, and reliability, serving the specific needs of German and European customers.

*Restrictions at GA: (1) SAP HANA Cloud, Data lake Relational Engine, (2) Joule in SAP HANA Cloud Central, (3) Customer-managed encryption keys (CMK), and (4) memory sizes larger than 7.5 TB.

entry.title: A Comprehensive Guide to SAP S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management (EWM)
entry.content:
A Comprehensive Guide to SAP S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management (EWM)

For End-Users, Key-Users, Beginners, and Consultants

Chapter 1: Introduction to SAP S/4HANA EWM

Welcome to the world of modern warehouse management with SAP S/4HANA EWM. This guide is designed to take you from the fundamental concepts to the execution of complex end-to-end processes. Whether you're an end-user performing daily tasks, a key-user helping to design solutions, or a consultant implementing the system, this document will serve as your practical handbook.

What is EWM?

Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) is SAP's strategic solution for managing inventory and supporting all logistics processes within a warehouse. It's a robust and flexible system designed to handle high-volume operations and provide granular control over every stock movement.

Think of a warehouse as a complex library. A basic inventory system (like Inventory Management or IM) knows which books the library owns. A more advanced system (like the older Warehouse Management or WM) knows which shelf each book is on. EWM is like the master librarian system: it not only knows the exact location of every book but also manages the tasks for the librarians (warehouse workers), plans the most efficient routes for them to retrieve or shelve books, manages the packing and shipping stations, and keeps a detailed history of every movement.

Key Differences: From ECC WM to S/4HANA EWM

If you're familiar with the classic SAP ERP WM module, you'll find EWM is a significant leap forward.

Feature

Classic WM (in SAP ECC)

S/4HANA EWM

Core Unit

Transfer Order (TO)

Warehouse Task (WT)

Structure

Relatively rigid (Warehouse > Storage Type > Bin)

More flexible (adds Storage Section, Activity Area)

Process Control

Limited process-oriented control.

Advanced, configurable Process-Oriented Storage Control (POSC).

Monitoring

Basic monitoring tools.

The Warehouse Monitor, a powerful, all-in-one tool.

Labor Management

Basic or non-existent in standard.

Integrated Labor Management and analytics.

Deployment

Always part of the ECC core.

Can be Embedded in S/4HANA or run as a Decentralized system.

The EWM Process Flow at a Glance

At its heart, every EWM process follows a simple logic: a trigger from an external business process (like a purchase or sales order) creates a requirement in the warehouse, which is then fulfilled through a series of structured tasks.

  1. Trigger (ERP): A Purchase Order is created for a vendor.
  2. Inbound Delivery Notification (EWM): When the vendor ships the goods, an Inbound Delivery is created in ERP, which replicates to EWM as a notification. This tells the warehouse, "Expect a delivery."
  3. Physical Inbound: The truck arrives. Workers unload the goods at the receiving dock (Goods Receipt Zone).
  4. Goods Receipt (EWM): The system posts the Goods Receipt. The stock now officially exists in the warehouse in a temporary receiving area.
  5. Putaway (EWM): The system creates Warehouse Tasks to move the goods from the receiving area to their final storage bins (e.g., high-rack shelves).
  6. Outbound Trigger (ERP): A customer places a Sales Order.
  7. Outbound Delivery Request (EWM): An Outbound Delivery is created in ERP, which replicates to EWM as a request to pick, pack, and ship.
  8. Picking (EWM): The system creates Warehouse Tasks for workers to pick the goods from their storage bins.
  9. Staging & Packing (EWM): Goods are moved to a packing station, packed into boxes (Handling Units), and then moved to a shipping or staging area.
  10. Goods Issue (EWM): The truck is loaded, and the system posts the Goods Issue. The stock is now removed from the warehouse inventory.

Introduction to the SAP Fiori Launchpad for EWM

In S/4HANA, the user experience is driven by the SAP Fiori Launchpad. It's a modern, role-based, and intuitive interface that replaces many of the old transaction codes. Throughout this guide, we will prioritize Fiori apps for executing business processes.

You'll interact with "tiles" that launch applications for tasks like "Post Goods Receipt," "Process Warehouse Tasks," or "Pack Outbound Deliveries."

Chapter 2: Core EWM Organizational Structure

Before you can move a single box, you must first build the digital twin of your warehouse in SAP. This structure defines all the physical areas and how they relate to each other and to the overall company structure (the Enterprise Structure).

The Link Between ERP and EWM Structures

The integration starts by linking a storage location in the ERP world to a warehouse in the EWM world.

  • Plant: Represents a physical location (e.g., a factory or distribution center).
  • Storage Location (SLoc): A subdivision of a Plant where stock is physically kept.
  • Warehouse Number: The highest-level organizational unit in EWM, representing the entire warehouse complex.

A single Plant can have multiple Storage Locations, and one or more of these can be managed by a single EWM Warehouse Number.

Customizing Point: Assign Warehouse Number to Plant/Storage Location

This is a foundational step in setting up the system. It tells SAP, "Any inventory posted to Plant 1010 and Storage Location 101E is subject to the rules and processes of EWM Warehouse W001."

  • Path (SPRO): SPRO -> Enterprise Structure -> Assignment -> Logistics Execution -> Assign warehouse number to plant/storage location
  • Example Configuration:

Plant

S.Loc

WhN

Description

1010

101E

W001

Main EWM-Managed Storage

1010

101A

 

Non-EWM Raw Materials

Warehouse Number (WhN)

This is the 3 or 4-character code representing your entire physical warehouse. For our guide, we will use W001.

Storage Type

A Storage Type is a physical area within your warehouse defined by its characteristics or the activities performed there. It's the primary level of subdivision.

  • Concept: Think of different sections in a supermarket: the refrigerated section, the dry goods aisles, the produce area, and the checkout counters. Each is a "storage type" with different properties.
  • Common Examples:
    • GRZ1: Goods Receipt Zone (temporary area for inbound goods).
    • GI_ZONE: Goods Issue Zone (temporary area for outbound goods).
    • RACK: Standard High-Rack Storage.
    • BULK: Bulk Storage Area for pallets on the floor.
    • PICK: A dedicated fast-picking area.
    • Q_ZONE: Quality Inspection Zone (the "Prison" area mentioned in source documents).

Customizing Point: Define Storage Type

Here you define the behavior of each area.

  • Path (SPRO): SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Master Data -> Define Storage Type
  • Key Parameters:
    • Storage Type Role: Defines the primary purpose (e.g., Standard, GR Zone, GI Zone).
    • HU Requirement: Must stock be in Handling Units (pallets, boxes)?
    • Putaway/Stock Removal Strategies: Defines the logic for finding a bin (e.g., Next Empty Bin, FIFO).
  • How-To Exercise:
    1. Navigate to the SPRO path.
    2. Click "New Entries".
    3. Create the storage type RACK for warehouse W001.
    4. Set the role to "Standard Storage".
    5. Set the "Putaway Rule" to "Empty Bin".
    6. Check the "HU Type Check" box to ensure only valid pallet types can be stored here.
    7. Save your entry.

Storage Section

A Storage Section is a logical or physical subdivision of a Storage Type. It's used to group bins with similar characteristics for putaway purposes.

  • Concept: Within the "dry goods aisles" (your RACK storage type), you might have one section for fast-moving items (like popular cereals, placed at the front of the aisle) and another for slow-moving items (specialty spices, placed higher up or at the back).
  • Examples: FAST (Fast-moving), SLOW (Slow-moving), HEAVY (for heavy items).

Customizing Point: Define Storage Section

  • Path (SPRO): SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Master Data -> Define Storage Section
  • How-To Exercise:
    1. Navigate to the SPRO path.
    2. Click "New Entries".
    3. For Warehouse W001 and Storage Type RACK, create two sections:
      • Section FAST: Description "Fast-Moving Items"
      • Section SLOW: Description "Slow-Moving Items"
    4. Save your entries.

Storage Bin

The Storage Bin is the smallest addressable unit of space in your warehouse. It's the final destination where products are physically stored.

  • Concept: A specific slot on a shelf in a specific aisle.
  • Naming Convention: A good naming convention is crucial for navigation. A common structure is AISLE-STACK-LEVEL. For example, 01-02-C could mean Aisle 01, Stack 02, Level C.
  • How-To: Create Storage Bins (/SCWM/LS10)

You don't create bins one by one. You use a generation tool.

    1. Go to transaction /SCWM/LS10 (or use the corresponding Fiori app).
    2. Enter your Warehouse W001 and Storage Type RACK.
    3. Define the structure of your bin names using a template. For example:
      • Structure: AA-SS-L
      • AA (Aisle): 01 to 10 (Numeric)
      • SS (Stack): 01 to 20 (Numeric)
      • L (Level): A to E (Alphabetic)
    4. Execute the transaction to generate thousands of bins instantly.

Activity Area

An Activity Area logically groups storage bins for specific warehouse activities like picking or physical inventory. This is the evolution of the "Picking Area" from classic WM.

  • Concept: To optimize a picker's travel path, you can group all bins in a single aisle into one picking Activity Area. The system can then sort all picking tasks for that aisle in the optimal sequence.
  • How-To: Define and Sort Activity Areas
    1. Define:
      • Path (SPRO): SCM Extended Warehouse Management -> Extended Warehouse Management -> Master Data -> Activity Areas -> Define Activity Area
      • Create an activity area, for example, PICK_A01 for Aisle 1.
    2. Assign Bins:
      • Path (SPRO): ... -> Activity Areas -> Assign Storage Bins to Activity Areas
      • Define a rule to assign all bins starting with 01- to activity area PICK_A01.
    3. Define Sort Sequence:
      • Path (SPRO): ... -> Activity Areas -> Define Sort Sequence for Activity Area
      • Define how tasks should be sorted for this area, for example, ascending by stack and then level, to create a snake-like picking path.

Chapter 3: Master Data in EWM

Master data is the foundation of all your processes. Incorrect master data leads to process failures.

Material Master / Product Master

The product master holds all information about a material. In S/4HANA, you use the Fiori App "Manage Product Master Data". For EWM, you must extend the material to include views for the warehouse.

  • Key Views:
    • General Plant Data / Storage 2: Contains weights and dimensions.
    • Warehouse Management: Links to the EWM-specific product master.

Warehouse Product Master (/SCWM/MAT1)

This is the EWM-specific extension of the material master. It holds all the data that is only relevant within the context of a specific warehouse.

  • How-To Access: Transaction /SCWM/MAT1 or via the "Warehouse" tab in the "Manage Product Master Data" Fiori App.
  • Key Fields on the "Warehouse Data" Tab:
    • Putaway Control Ind. (PACI): A key that triggers the putaway strategy. For example, a PACI of FAST could tell the system to look for a bin in the FAST storage section first.
    • Stock Removal Cntrl Ind. (SRCI): A key that triggers the picking strategy (e.g., strict FIFO).
  • Key Fields on the "Slotting" Tab:
    • Used for slotting optimization (determining the best bin for a product).
  • Key Fields on the "Packaging" Tab:
    • Defines standard quantities for different packaging units (e.g., 1 PALLET = 10 CARTONS/BOXES = 100 PIECES).

Master Data Exercise

  1. Create a Finished Good:
    • Use Fiori app "Manage Product Master Data".
    • Create a new product, e.g., EWM-FG-100 (Premium Coffee Maker).
    • Fill in basic data, sales data, and MRP data.
    • Extend it to Plant 1010 and Storage Location 101E.
    • Enter gross weight: 5 KG.
  2. Maintain Warehouse Product Master:
    • Go to transaction /SCWM/MAT1.
    • Enter your product EWM-FG-100 and Warehouse W001.
    • On the "Warehouse Data" tab, set the "Putaway Control Ind." to ST_RACK (for standard rack putaway).
    • On the "Packaging" tab, define a Packaging Specification for palletizing (more on this later).
    • Save your product.

Packaging Specifications (Pack Spec)

This powerful master data object defines how a product is to be packed. It dictates the hierarchy of packaging materials and quantities.

  • Example: For EWM-FG-100, a Pack Spec could define:
    • Level 1: 1 PIECE goes into a small box (EWM-BOX-S).
    • Level 2: 10 small boxes go into a large carton (EWM-CARTON-L).
    • Level 3: 5 large cartons are stacked on a pallet (EWM-PALLET-EUR).

This is crucial for automated packing instructions and for creating Handling Units (HUs).

Chapter 4: The Inbound Process: From Purchase to Putaway

This chapter walks you through the complete end-to-end process for receiving goods from an external supplier. This corresponds to the SAP Best Practice Scope Item 1FS (Warehouse Inbound Processing from Supplier).

Scenario Overview

We need to restock our Premium Coffee Maker (EWM-FG-100). We will order 50 units from our supplier. The supplier will ship them, and we will receive them, check them, and put them away into our RACK storage area.

Step 1: Create a Purchase Order

This process starts in the procurement department, outside the warehouse.

  • Application: Fiori App "Manage Purchase Orders".
  • Action:
    1. Create a new Purchase Order.
    2. Supplier: Enter your supplier ID.
    3. Material: EWM-FG-100.
    4. Quantity: 50 EA.
    5. Plant: 1010.
    6. Storage Location: 101E (This is the crucial link to trigger the EWM process).
    7. Save the Purchase Order. Note the PO number (e.g., 4500001234).

Step 2: Post Goods Receipt and Create Inbound Delivery

When the truck from the supplier arrives, the first step is to record the receipt. In S/4HANA EWM, the best practice is to post the goods receipt against the Purchase Order, which automatically creates the Inbound Delivery.

  • Application: Fiori App "Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document".
  • Action:
    1. Enter the Purchase Order number 4500001234.
    2. The system will propose the items and quantities from the PO.
    3. Verify the quantity is correct (50 EA).
    4. Check the "Post" button.
    5. Upon posting, the system does two things simultaneously:
      • It posts the material document (MIGO in the background), increasing stock in Plant 1010 / SLoc 101E.
      • It creates an Inbound Delivery which is automatically replicated to the EWM system.

Step 3: Process the Inbound Delivery in EWM

Now, the warehouse team takes over in the EWM system. The goods are physically at the receiving dock (GRZ1 storage type).

  • Application: Fiori App "Process Warehouse Tasks - Unloading" or the Warehouse Monitor (/SCWM/MON).
  • Action:
    1. Search for your Inbound Delivery (using the PO number or delivery number).
    2. You will see the delivery with a status of "Ready for Putaway".
    3. The stock is currently sitting in a temporary bin in the GRZ1 storage type.

Step 4: Create and Confirm Putaway Warehouse Tasks

The final step is to move the goods from the receiving dock to their final home in the warehouse. This is done via Warehouse Tasks (WTs).

  • Application: Fiori App "Process Warehouse Tasks" or directly from the Inbound Delivery screen.
  • Action (System):
    1. Select your Inbound Delivery line item and click "Create Warehouse Task".
    2. The system will now execute its putaway strategy:
      • It reads the Putaway Control Indicator (ST_RACK) from the Warehouse Product Master for EWM-FG-100.
      • This indicator points to a search sequence that tells the system to look for a bin in Storage Type RACK.
      • Within RACK, the "Empty Bin" rule is applied.
      • The system finds the next available empty bin, e.g., 01-01-A, and proposes it as the destination bin.
  • Action (User - RF Device Simulation):

In a real warehouse, a worker would get this task on their RF scanner. We can simulate this.

    1. Go to transaction /SCWM/RFUI (RF User Interface).
    2. Log in with your warehouse and resource details.
    3. Navigate through the menu: 01 Inbound Processes -> 03 Putaway -> 01 Putaway by HU.
    4. Scan the Handling Unit (HU) number that was created during goods receipt.
    5. The system will display the task: MOVE EWM-FG-100 FROM GR-ZONE TO 01-01-A.
    6. To confirm, you would scan the destination bin 01-01-A.
    7. Once confirmed, the task is complete. The stock is now physically and systemically located in bin 01-01-A.

Process Complete: The goods are now available in the warehouse for future sales orders.

Chapter 5: The Outbound Process: From Sales to Shipping

This chapter details the complete process of fulfilling a customer order, from sales order creation to the final goods issue. This corresponds to the SAP Best Practice Scope Item 1G0 (Warehouse Outbound Processing).

Scenario Overview

A customer, "HyperMart Inc.", places an order for 20 Premium Coffee Makers (EWM-FG-100). Our job is to pick the items from the warehouse, pack them, and ship them to the customer.

Step 1: Create a Sales Order

The process begins with the sales department.

  • Application: Fiori App "Manage Sales Orders".
  • Action:
    1. Create a new Sales Order.
    2. Customer: Enter the Business Partner ID for "HyperMart Inc.".
    3. Material: EWM-FG-100.
    4. Quantity: 20 EA.
    5. Check the availability. The system will confirm that stock is available in Plant 1010 / SLoc 101E.
    6. Save the Sales Order. Note the order number.

Step 2: Create the Outbound Delivery

Based on the delivery date in the sales order, the logistics team creates an Outbound Delivery.

  • Application: Fiori App "Create Outbound Deliveries from Sales Orders".
  • Action:
    1. Enter your selection criteria (e.g., shipping point, sales order number, delivery creation date).
    2. The system will list the sales order item that is due for shipment.
    3. Select the item and execute.
    4. An Outbound Delivery is created and automatically replicated to EWM as an Outbound Delivery Request.

Step 3: Process the Outbound Delivery in EWM (Picking)

The warehouse team now has an active request to fulfill.

  • Application: Fiori App "Run Outbound Process - Deliveries".
  • Action:
    1. Search for your Outbound Delivery Request.
    2. Select the delivery and choose the follow-on function "Create Warehouse Tasks".
    3. System Logic (Stock Removal Strategy):
      • The system determines it needs 20 EA of EWM-FG-100.
      • It checks the product master for the Stock Removal Cntrl Ind. (e.g., FIFO).
      • It finds the oldest stock of the product in the warehouse, which is in bin 01-01-A.
      • It creates a Picking Warehouse Task to move 20 EA from bin 01-01-A to a packing station (e.g., PACK.STATION.01).
  • Action (User - RF Confirmation):
    1. The picker sees the task on their RF device.
    2. They navigate to bin 01-01-A.
    3. They scan the bin to confirm the location.
    4. They pick 20 units and scan the product to confirm.
    5. They transport the goods to the packing station and scan the station's bin PACK.STATION.01 to confirm the drop-off.
    6. The picking task is now confirmed. The stock has moved systemically from the storage bin to the packing station.

Step 4: Packing

At the packing station, the picker or a dedicated packer will pack the goods into shipping cartons.

  • Application: Fiori App "Pack Outbound Deliveries".
  • Action:
    1. Enter the packing station PACK.STATION.01.
    2. The system shows the 20 units of EWM-FG-100 that are ready to be packed.
    3. Create a new Handling Unit (HU) by selecting a packaging material (e.g., a large shipping box, SHIP-BOX-L). The system will generate a unique HU number (e.g., a license plate number).
    4. "Drag and drop" the 20 units into the new HU.
    5. Close the HU. It is now a sealed, labeled shipping container.

Step 5: Staging and Goods Issue

The final step is to move the packed HU to the shipping dock and post the goods issue when the truck leaves.

  • Application: RF Device or Fiori App.
  • Action:
    1. A warehouse task is created to move the packed HU from PACK.STATION.01 to the Goods Issue Zone (GI_ZONE). This is confirmed by a warehouse worker.
    2. The HUs are loaded onto the truck.
    3. Once loading is complete, go to the Fiori App "Run Outbound Process - Deliveries".
    4. Select your Outbound Delivery and click "Post Goods Issue".
  • System Result:
    • Inventory is reduced in EWM and ERP.
    • The delivery document is updated.
    • Billing in Sales and Distribution (SD) can now proceed.
    • Financial postings are made in the background.

Process Complete: The customer's order has been successfully shipped.

Chapter 9: Comprehensive Test Plan

This chapter provides a set of structured test scenarios to validate the end-to-end EWM processes configured in your S/4HANA system. Each scenario includes prerequisites, step-by-step instructions, and expected outcomes.

Introduction & Prerequisites

  • Objective: To provide a hands-on, practical way to learn and test the core EWM flows.
  • Prerequisites:
    1. All organizational structures (Chapter 2) have been configured.
    2. All master data (Chapter 3) has been created (Products, Business Partners, etc.).
    3. Users have the necessary authorizations for the Fiori apps mentioned.
    4. Initial stock for the test materials must exist in the warehouse to perform the outbound scenarios.

Test Scenario 1: Procure to Stock (Based on Inbound Process)

  • Description: This scenario tests the complete inbound logistics process from procurement to final putaway in the warehouse.
  • SAP Scope Item: 1FS
  • Test Data:
    • Material: EWM-RM-200 (Raw Material - Plastic Pellets)
    • Supplier: SUPPLIER-1001
    • Quantity: 1000 KG
    • Plant / SLoc: 1010 / 101E

Step

Action

Application / T-Code

Expected Result

Tester

Status (OK/NOK)

Comments

1

Create Purchase Order for 1000 KG of EWM-RM-200.

Fiori: "Manage Purchase Orders"

Purchase Order is created and saved. A PO number is generated.

   

2

Post Goods Receipt against the Purchase Order.

Fiori: "Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document"

Material Document is posted. An Inbound Delivery is created and replicated to EWM. Stock appears in the GRZ1 storage type.

   

3

Verify Inbound Delivery in EWM.

/SCWM/MON

The Inbound Delivery exists in the monitor with a status of "Ready for Putaway".

   

4

Create Putaway Warehouse Task.

/SCWM/MON or Fiori App

The system proposes a valid empty bin in the correct storage type (e.g., BULK) based on the product's putaway strategy. A WT is created.

   

5

Confirm Putaway Warehouse Task.

RFUI: /SCWM/RFUI

The warehouse task is confirmed.

   

6

Check Final Stock Position.

Fiori: "Stock - Single Material"

The stock of 1000 KG of EWM-RM-200 is visible in the final destination bin. The Inbound Delivery is marked as "Completed".

   

Test Scenario 2: Plan to Produce & Goods Receipt

  • Description: This scenario tests the staging of components for a production order and the receipt of the finished product into the EWM-managed warehouse.
  • SAP Scope Item: 1F0
  • Test Data:
    • Finished Good: EWM-FG-100 (Premium Coffee Maker)
    • Component: EWM-RM-200 (Plastic Pellets)
    • Production Order Quantity: 10 EA
    • Production Supply Area (PSA): PSA-ASSY-01

Step

Action

Application / T-Code

Expected Result

Tester

Status (OK/NOK)

Comments

1

Create & Release Production Order for 10 EA of EWM-FG-100.

Fiori: "Manage Production Orders"

A Production Order is created. A Production Material Request (PMR) is automatically generated in EWM for the required components.

   

2

Stage Components for Production.

EWM: /SCWM/PMR or Fiori

Create Warehouse Tasks for the PMR. This will create a picking task to move EWM-RM-200 from its storage bin to the Production Supply Area PSA-ASSY-01.

   

3

Confirm Staging Warehouse Task.

RFUI: /SCWM/RFUI

The picking task is confirmed. The components are now available for production.

   

4

Confirm Production Order Yield.

Fiori: "Confirm Production Order"

Post a confirmation for 10 EA of EWM-FG-100. This triggers a goods receipt in the background.

   

5

Receive Finished Goods in EWM.

EWM: Inbound Delivery is created automatically.

An Inbound Delivery for 10 EA of EWM-FG-100 appears in EWM. The stock is in the GRZ1 from production.

   

6

Putaway Finished Goods.

/SCWM/MON -> Create & Confirm WT

Warehouse tasks are created and confirmed to move the 10 Coffee Makers to their final bin in the RACK storage type.

   

Test Scenario 3: Order to Cash (Outbound)

  • Description: This scenario tests the complete outbound process, from the customer's order to the final shipment.
  • SAP Scope Item: 1G0
  • Test Data:
    • Material: EWM-FG-100 (Premium Coffee Maker)
    • Customer: CUST-2001
    • Quantity: 5 EA

Step

Action

Application / T-Code

Expected Result

Tester

Status (OK/NOK)

Comments

1

Create Sales Order for 5 EA of EWM-FG-100.

Fiori: "Manage Sales Orders"

Sales Order is created and saved.

   

2

Create Outbound Delivery.

Fiori: "Create Outbound Deliveries from Sales Orders"

An Outbound Delivery is created and replicated to EWM as an Outbound Delivery Request.

   

3

Create Picking Warehouse Tasks in EWM.

Fiori: "Run Outbound Process - Deliveries"

The system creates a picking task based on the FIFO strategy from the RACK storage type to the PACK.STATION.01.

   

4

Confirm Picking Task.

RFUI: /SCWM/RFUI

The picking task is confirmed. Stock has moved to the packing station.

   

5

Pack the goods into a Handling Unit (HU).

Fiori: "Pack Outbound Deliveries"

The 5 EA are packed into a shipping box. A unique HU number is generated.

   

6

Post Goods Issue.

Fiori: "Run Outbound Process - Deliveries"

Goods Issue is posted. Stock is deducted from inventory. Financial documents are created. The process is complete.

entry.title: Re: How to handle tax-included items
entry.content:
Hi Team,

Hope the message can find you well!

If you want to use the tax-inclusive price, you can consider to the configuration in the blog (Which is written using Chinese) below：

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/s-4-hana-cloud-workaround-%E9%94%80%E5%94%AE%E5%90%AB%E7%A8%8E%E4%BB%B7/ba-p/13509670

In detailed, you need to create the Z998 (The tax-inclusive price), ZEXC(Output tax) , ZPPR(Net Price) and ZRD1(Rounding difference), and then calculate the ZPPR using BAdI.

As a result, you can maintain the tax-inclusive price and the BAdI will calculated the net price.

More details and configuration can be found from the blog above.

Have a nice day!

Best Regards,

Joey

entry.title: How to set the Org Memory Limit for a Cloud Foundry instance via Terraform?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Test Data Conversion, the accelerator: scaling smart
entry.content:
In our Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Community Blog, we explored Test Data Conversion (TDC) and Test Data Refresh (TDR), the potential pathways for test system readiness as part of the 3 SL post-conversion activity. We have also seen the unique value added by both the services. If you're seeking deeper insight into Test Data Conversion (TDC), you're in the right place. In this blog we will see a comprehensive overview of TDC, purpose, and value added by TDC.  

Customer satisfaction is the cornerstone of any business. To ensure a seamless transition into 3 SL conversion, TDC is being offered as a one-time complimentary service to all the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 3 SL conversion customers by SAP. 

Before we delve into the full scope and benefits of TDC, Let’s have an understanding on the key prerequisites for TDC implementation. 

TDC Pre-requisites: 

To ensure a seamless and efficient data transfer during the TDC enablement process, below key prerequisites must be fulfilled at the system level: 

  1. Uniform Software Release Across all tenants: 
    • All Tenants must operate on the same software release configuration. 
    • This consistency helps eliminate system discrepancies and ensures reliable data flow. 
  2. System Configuration Maintenance 
    • A well-maintained System configuration is essential for seamless TDC execution. 
    • It supports system stability there by reduces integration friction.  
  3. Content Version Alignment 
    • All tenants should be in the same content version release. 
    • Version mismatches can lead to errors during data transfer and could lead to incomplete data mapping.  
  4. Extension Readiness 
    • Ensure all relevant extensions are active and configured with the latest updates. 
    • The Handle Your Extensions app will come handy to verify and manage extensions efficiently. 
  5. Clean Development Transport Queue 
    • Confirm that there are no open transports in the development queue. 
    • The transport queue should be clean to avoid data inconsistency or conflicts. 

Note:  if you need help with the first three prerequisites, The conversion team will help you to validate and maintain the necessary configurations across tenants. This simplifies the process and ensures readiness for TDC onboarding. 

TDC: Enabling Seamless Data Transition for tenant post-conversion 

The TDC service offers a powerful solution for transferring reliable data from the development tenant to the test tenant. It supports the migration of: 

  • Master Data 
  • Transactional Data 
  • Historical Test Data 
  • System Configurations (e.g., Output Management and others) 

 By this, TDC will not only take care of data, but also help in setting up certain configurations thereby reduces manual setup efforts and accelerate system readiness process. One of the critical components in system setup is the Output Management Configuration. TDC streamlines this process by automatically transferring output management configuration data from the development tenant to the new test tenant. In addition to configuration data, TDC also migrates all available test automation assets, ensuring that testing frameworks and scripts are ready to resume at the earliest. 

One of the key concerns during data migration is data privacy. TDC service offers depersonalization as an optional feature, which ensures sensitive information (Workforce data is out of scope) is anonymized during the transfer process. 

Note: Depersonalization is a broad and critical topic. While this blog focuses on understanding TDC, reference links will be provided below for those who wish to explore depersonalization in detail. 

Once the data migration via TDC is complete, the system reaches a near-ready state, as a next step initiate Rewiring of Applications as a Post migration step to ensure the alignment of applications with the new test tenant. This step ensures seamless integration with applications and functionality across the system landscape. 

Note: Rewiring of apps is beyond the scope of this blog. Kindly refer to SAP help page for those who wish to explore Rewiring of apps in more detail. 

With consistent and complete data in place and successful rewiring of apps, the test tenant becomes fully operational. This marks the transition of test tenant from setup to active usage. All available test automation scripts from the development tenant can now be resumed. This helps to validate system integrity, confirm readiness, and ensure smooth performance post conversion. 

Conclusion: 

In this Blog, we’ve explored the pre-requisite, scope of TDC. We've also seen how TDC significantly reducing manual effort and saving time during the 3 SL post conversion process. 

We hope this has provided you with a comprehensive and clear understanding of TDC, its benefits, and its role in enabling a smoother transition to the new Test tenant. 

 Reference: 

  • Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Community
  • 3SL Conversion for two-system landscape customers managed by SAP Central Business Configuration
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3SL onboarding and initial system set-up series
  • Streamlining 3SL Post Conversion Steps: Introducing CIAS and TDC Services
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/test-data-refresh-service-request-on-sap-f...

For more details about the Handle Your Extensions app and its use, refer to the Blog - Handle Your Extensions - test data refresh.

entry.title: Enabling Agent Interoperability: A Practical Path from API to MCP Server
entry.content:
The future of enterprise AI will be driven by the deep and seamless integration of LLMs into existing enterprise products and workflows. To stay competitive, companies must make their vast landscape of existing capabilities directly accessible and usable by AI, empowering a new generation of intelligent ecosystems. This requires a clear strategy for enabling agent interoperability.

In this article, we will establish that the journey to agent interoperability begins with a foundational pillar: enabling agents to reliably connect with tools (Agent-to-Tool). We'll start by defining the foundational challenge that prevents agents and tools from communicating effectively. We will then introduce the Model Context Protocol (MCP) as a standardized solution and walk through a step-by-step tutorial on how to transform a standard REST API into a fully compliant MCP Server using a cloud-native gateway.

 

What is Agent Interoperability and Why Does It Matter?

Agent Interoperability is a comprehensive framework for a complete AI ecosystem, which relies on two fundamental pillars: Agent-to-Agent (A2A) interaction and Agent-to-Tool (A2T) interaction.

While A2A interaction—how agents collaborate and delegate tasks—represents a sophisticated, multi-agent system's goal, A2T interaction is the foundational prerequisite. The ability of agents to collaborate is contingent upon their individual capacity to connect to tools.

Therefore, solving the Agent-to-Tool challenge is the most critical first step towards the broader goal of agent interoperability. While not an Agent-to-Agent protocol itself, solving the Agent-to-Tool challenge is the most critical first step towards the broader goal of agent interoperability: how to let any agent discover and use any external capability in a standardized way.

 

Foundational Challenge: Connecting Agents to Enterprise Tools

In an enterprise environment like SAP, this challenge presents distinct engineering considerations on both sides of the connection:

  • On the agent side: The challenge is building agents with the autonomy to dynamically discover and utilize a diverse set of capabilities, moving beyond static tool integrations.
  • On the capability side: The engineering task is to adapt SAP's vast landscape of powerful APIs for a new type of consumer: the autonomous AI agent. The goal is to create AI-consumable interfaces for these existing capabilities, which involves adding the necessary semantic context and standardized formats that agents require for dynamic interaction.

This difference in design paradigms creates a natural "Interoperability Gap”. Bridging this gap requires a foundational layer for communication: a standardized protocol that enables dynamic discovery and standardized interaction between agents and established enterprise APIs.

 

The Solution: MCP as a Standardized Protocol Bridge

So, how do we bridge this "Interoperability Gap"? The solution lies in a shared standard—a common language that both agents and tools can speak. This is where the Model Context Protocol (MCP)  comes in.

MCP is an open protocol that standardizes how applications provide context to large language models (LLMs). MCP provides a standardized way to connect AI models to different data sources and tools.

We use MCP to build agents and complex workflows on top of LLMs. The key participants in the MCP architecture are:

  • MCP Host: The AI application that coordinates and manages one or multiple MCP clients
  • MCP Client: A component that maintains a connection to an MCP server and obtains context from an MCP server for the MCP host to use
  • MCP Server: A program that provides context to MCP clients

As for enterprise like SAP, the best practice will be:

However, a protocol is only useful if capabilities adopt it. The enterprise landscape is filled with valuable, pre-existing REST APIs that were not built for this new paradigm. Therefore, a critical first step toward achieving agent interoperability is to bridge these legacy APIs to the MCP standard.

The act of transforming a standard API into a discoverable MCP Server is the foundational process for unlocking existing enterprise value for AI agents. 

 

MCP Adoption Strategy in Enterprise Ecosystems

When adopting a new standard like MCP within a large enterprise ecosystem like SAP, there are typically two primary strategic paths to consider for implementation:

1. The Standard Path: Platform-Managed Solutions

For most common use cases, the standard approach is to leverage platform-integrated, centrally managed solutions. This path involves using automated services, often provided by the enterprise platform (e.g., SAP BTP), to convert existing APIs into standardized tools. By using unified method for transformation, this approach ensures consistency and manageability across the entire ecosystem.

2. The Flexible Path: Custom or "Native" Implementations

For scenario demanding greater flexibility or more complex business logic, a more custom approach is required. This involves building what can be considered "native" MCP servers. This approach allows teams to build custom implementations using a variety of technologies, such as open-source libraries or different programming languages, giving them full control over the implementation.

This Guide's Focus: A Hands-on Example of the Flexible Path

In the following guide, we will focus on the flexible, native server approach.  We will demonstrate a powerful and practical pattern for this by using a cloud-native gateway, Higress, to wrap an existing API. This method is ideal for teams who require full control over the transformation logic and deployment environment, providing a valuable, hands-on example of building a native-style MCP server.

 

Step-by-Step Guide: Transforming API into MCP Server

To see how this concept works in the real world, let's take a standard REST API and use a gateway to transform it into a fully-compliant MCP server.

Our Goal: Wrap a simple HTTP API as an MCP Server and invoke it from an agent.

Our Tools:

  • A Simple API: A REST API that returns real-time currency exchange data.
  • The Gateway: Higress, an open-source, cloud-native gateway with a powerful plugin architecture.
  • The Standard: The Model Context Protocol (MCP), which we'll implement using the Higress MCP Plugin.
  • The Environment: A Kubernetes environment.

 

A Modern Transport Protocol: Streamable HTTP

Before we begin, it's important to understand transport mechanisms for client-server communication we'll be using. This guide utilizes a modern and powerful approach defined by the MCP standard: Streamable HTTP.

We chose this approach for several key advantages that make it superior for modern AI systems:

  • Simplified Architecture: In the Streamable HTTP transport, the server operates as an independent process that can handle multiple client connections. Because the session context is maintained within this single, stateful connection, the need for an external session manager like Redis is often eliminated.
  • Bidirectional and Flexible Communication: The protocol handles simple request-response patterns efficiently but also enables true bidirectional communication. Server can optionally make use of Server-Sent Events (SSE) to stream multiple server messages. This permits basic MCP servers, as well as more feature-rich servers supporting streaming and server-to-client notifications and requests.

 

Step 1: The Starting Point - A Simple REST API

As the requirement of Streamable HTTP, The server MUST provide a single HTTP endpoint path (hereafter referred to as the MCP endpoint) that supports both POST and GET methods.

To demonstrate the transformation process, this guide will use the ExchangeRate-API, a professional service that provides real-time currency exchange data. We'll use its lasted endpoint, which returns up-to-date global rates based on the US Dollar.

  • API Endpoint: https://open.er-api.com/v6/latest/USD

A successful request to this endpoint returns a JSON object with a structure similar to this, containing metadata and a nested rates object:

{
  "result": "success",
  "time_last_update_utc": "Mon, 15 Sep 2025 00:02:31 +0000",
  "base_code": "USD",
  "rates": {
    "USD": 1,
    "EUR": 0.925,
    "GBP": 0.789,
    ...
  }
}

This represents a typical "legacy" capability—useful, but not inherently agent-friendly. 

 

Step 2: Preparing the Gateway with Higress

Instead of modifying the API's code, we'll use a gateway to act as a transformation layer. Higress is an ideal choice because its plugin architecture is designed to extend gateway capabilities, including native support for AI scenarios through protocols like MCP.

2.1 Higress Deployment

First, install Higress into your cluster environment (To simplify, we use k3s as an example).

Check your console's node port:

kubectl get svc higress-console -n higress-system

Once the installation succeeds, you can access the Higress Console in browser by http://<your-cluster-external-ip>:<console-port>.  

 

2.2 Config MCP Server

Once deployed, we need to enable the MCP Server functionality globally by editing the higress-config ConfigMap.

kubectl edit configmap higress-config -n higress-system

In the ConfigMap data, we'll add the MCP Server configuration. 

apiVersion: v1
data:
  higress: |-
    mcpServer:
      sse_path_suffix: /sse  # Suffix for the Server-Sent Events connection path
      enable: true           # Enable the MCP Server
      servers: []
  downstream:
    # ... (rest of the config)

 

Step 3: Transforming the API with the MCP Plugin

3.1 Add a Service Source

In the Higress Console, navigate to Service Source page http://<your-cluster-external-ip>:<console-port>/service-source  and add a new source pointing to our API's address (https://open.er-api.com/v6/latest/USD).

 

3.2 Create a Route

Next, go to the Route page and create a new route.

  • Click "Route Config" on the left sidebar
  • Click "Create Route" button
  • Fill in the form with the following details:
    • Route Name: exchange-rate-route
    • Path: Select Exact and enter /exchange-rates
    • Target Service: Select the service source you just created

This will create a route that matches the path /exchange-rates and forwards requests to the service source you created. Now you can see the new route in the list.

At this point, Higress will simply proxy requests from /exchange-rates to our API.

 

3. Configure the MCP Server Plugin

Click the Strategy link on your new route and find the MCP Server plugin.

 

After enabling the plugin, click "Configure" and switch to the YAML view. This is where we define the metadata that makes our API discoverable and understandable to agents.

 

Paste the following configuration:

server:
  name: "exchange-rate-server"
tools:
  - name: "get-latest-usd-rates"
    description: "Fetches the latest currency exchange rates based on the US Dollar."
    requestTemplate:
      method: "GET"
      url: "https://open.er-api.com/v6/latest/USD"
    responseTemplate:
      body: |-
        **Latest Exchange Rates (Base: {{.base_code}})**
        *Updated at: {{.time_last_update_utc}}*
        
        - **Euro (EUR):** {{.rates.EUR}}
        - **Japanese Yen (JPY):** {{.rates.JPY}}
        - **British Pound (GBP):** {{.rates.GBP}}
        - **Chinese Yuan (CNY):** {{.rates.CNY}}

Let's break this down:

  • server.name: A human-readable name for our new MCP server.
  • tools: A list of capabilities this server provides.
  • name & description: The crucial metadata for agent to intelligently discover and select this tool when a user asks about exchange rates.
  • requestTemplate & responseTemplate: These define how Higress calls the backend API and formats the response. Here, the requestTemplate specifies a simple GET request, and the responseTemplate transforms the JSON output into a clean, agent-friendly format.

Save the plugin configuration. Our standard REST API is now exposed as a fully functional and discoverable MCP Server, ready for any compliant AI agent to use.

 

Step 4: Connecting and Invoking from an Agent with Streamable HTTP

Now, any MCP-compliant agent or client can connect to our gateway and use this new tool. To test our new MCP server, we can use any compliant MCP Host app, such as Cline, Cursor, Trae, etc.

For this guide, we'll use Cline as example. It's an autonomous coding agent that can be installed as a VS Code extension. Configure Cline with the following setting to establish a connection to our new server:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "exchange-rate-server": {
      "url": "http://<your-cluster-external-ip>/exchange-rates",
      "type": "streamableHttp"
    }
  }
}

Now you can test the server in Cline:

 

Wrapping Up

In this post, we've navigated a practical path toward the broader vision of agent interoperability. We established that the most critical first step is solving the Agent-to-Tool (A2T) challenge: making existing enterprise APIs discoverable and usable by AI agents. We then demonstrated a powerful pattern to achieve this, using a cloud-native gateway, Higress, to transform a standard REST API into a fully compliant MCP Server.

The most powerful takeaway is demonstrating a flexible path to a native server: You've learned how a gateway-centric pattern can be used to build a "native" MCP server, offering full control to teams that require flexibility and customization in their MCP adoption strategy. It means existing, valuable enterprise services can be rapidly integrated into the agent ecosystem, making them dynamically discoverable and usable by any MCP-compliant agent.

Solving the Agent-to-Tool problem building the foundation for agent interoperability. With a robust A2T layer in place, the path is cleared for more advanced Agent-to-Agent collaboration, paves the way for a future where countless enterprise services can be seamlessly integrated with agent ecosystem.

entry.title: Re: How to create record Technical Object in Change Sales...
entry.content:
Hi Phuhs,

You can set up automatic serial number creation for sales orders in the serial number profile customizing. You have to set procedure SDAU (Serial numbers in SD order) to 04 (Automatic) for your serial number profile.

If you want to influence the automatic numbering via BAdI, you can use BAdI LOSN_SER_NUM_INT_CREATE for developer extensibility (Eclipse ADT) or LOSN_CBO_SERIAL_NUMBER_INT for key user extensibility (Custom Logic app).
The corresponding help document: 
https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/20f4d8b2420544f7a5e41471c5bf5dac.html

BR,
Alex
